isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 2000, 4000, 8000 - ELECTRONIC ENGINES, CUMMINS M11E AND N14E - OPERATION - Accelerator Pedal Assembly (309)

svcprocinfo.para: CELECT engines use an electronic accelerator pedal assembly that uses an integratedAccelerator Position Sensor (APS)/Idle Validation Switch (IVS). The sensor is not serviceable and if defective, must be replaced and recalibrated to the ECM.

svcsubproc.title: Accelerator Position Sensor (APS)
svcsubproc.para: The APS is attached to the accelerator pedal. The APS acts like a potentiometer-movement of the pedal results in a variable signal being sent to the ECM that is proportional to pedal position.
The 5V signal from ECM connector (320) terminal 18 is applied on circuit 99A(5V) to APS/IVS connector (309) terminal C.

The variable wiper signal (varies with pedal position) from APS/IVS connector (309) terminal A, returns on circuit 99, to ECM connector (320) terminal 11. This variable signal tells the ECM the position of the accelerator pedal.
The APS is grounded through APS/IVS connector (309) terminal B on circuit 99-G, to ECM connector (320) terminal 19.

note.para: Any time the accelerator pedal sensor (APS) is disconnected from the ECM with the key switch on, the APS and ECM must be recalibrated (refer to Calibrating Accelerator To ECM below).

svcsubproc.title: IDLE VALIDATION SWITCH (IVS)
svcsubproc.para: The IVS is used to indicate when accelerator pedal is in the low idle position and when the pedal is not in the low idle position.

With the accelerator in the low idle position, contacts of the IVS are closed and a ground path is applied to ECM connector (320) terminal 6. From this terminal the path is circuit 99B, connector (3), circuit 99B, connector (309), the IVS, connector (309), circuit 99-GA/97-GA, connector (3), and circuit 97-GA/97-G to the ECM (320) common ground terminal 10. This indicates to the ECM that the accelerator pedal is at idle position.

When the accelerator is not in the low idle position, the idle contacts of the IVS are open and the normally open throttle contacts of the IVS are closed. This applies a ground path to ECM connector (320) terminal 9. From this terminal the path is circuit 99C, connector (3), circuit 99C, connector (309), the IVS, connector (309), circuit 99-GA/97-GA, connector (3), and circuit 97-GA/97-G to the ECM (320) common ground terminal 10. This indicates to the ECM that the accelerator pedal is not at idle position.

svcsubproc.title: APS/IVS INTERACTION
svcsubproc.para: The ECM analyzes the signals received from the APS and IVS signals making certain that the signals fall within certain parameters. For example: if the IVS signal indicates that the accelerator pedal is in the IDLE position, the ECM expects to see an APS signal that indicates that no throttle is applied. If it does not see a logical response from both, a fault code may be logged. The APS/IVS timing cannot be checked using a multimeter.

svcsubproc.title: CALIBRATING ACCELERATOR TO ECM
svcsubproc.para: The signals between the ECM and the accelerator pedal are low voltage (5V) and very low current (microamps). Because of these low voltages and currents, they must be electrically calibrated to one another for proper engine response.
The ECM and accelerator pedal must be calibrated:

item.para: When the accelerator pedal is initially installed
When an accelerator pedal is replaced
When a new calibration is down-loaded to the ECM
When the accelerator pedal wiring is disconnected either at the pedal or at connector (320) while the key switch is on

svcsubproc.para: To recalibrate the ECM and the accelerator pedal - the key must be on, then the accelerator pedal must be slowly and fully depressed from idle to full throttle and then released. The accelerator pedal should be depressed and released three times.
